text: Hey, I've started working on a new string format library: <https://github.com/bicycle1885/Fmt.jl>. In short, it brings the Python-style format (or std::format of C++, or std::fmt of Rust) to Julia. It's still pre-alpha, but almost all tools are implemented. Your feedback is welcomed!

elements.text: Hey, I've started working on a new string format library:
. In short, it brings the Python-style format (or std::format of C++, or std::fmt of Rust) to Julia. It's still pre-alpha, but almost all tools are implemented. Your feedback is welcomed!

text: Looks cool! How does it compare to the `Printf` stdlib?

elements.text: Looks cool! How does it compare to the
Printf
stdlib?

elements.text: I like the mix of interpolation with the format specification

text: amazing that this doesn't need special language support, other than string macros!

elements.text: amazing that this doesn't need special language support, other than string macros!

text: I wonder where the allocations for `fmt_print` are coming from :thinking_face:

elements.text: I wonder where the allocations for
fmt_print
are coming from

text: Thank you! In terms of interface, Fmt.jl is simpler because you can mix string interpolation and formatting into a format syntax. Also, type specifiers are optional in Fmt.jl, while C-style Printf.jl requires them. In terms of performance, Fmt.jl seems to be slightly faster (may be 2x?) in some cases. I've updated the performance section accordingly. Of course, it needs more exhaustive benchmarks.

elements.text: Thank you! In terms of interface, Fmt.jl is simpler because you can mix string interpolation and formatting into a format syntax. text: The benchmark benchmarks the cost of formatted string creation. So, it always allocates. It needs to allocates two objects: one for a string and one for a wrapper vector of it.

text: I had a problem with measurements and sprintf, that required to define Printf.tofloat on measurements, as Float64(measure) is not defined. I mention this because this package has related funcionality

text: The lack of docs is due to my procrastination. I'll do that before releasing it. But it's mostly compatible with Python, so you can refer to the docs of Python.

elements.text: The lack of docs is due to my procrastination. I'll do that before releasing it. But it's mostly compatible with Python, so you can refer to the docs of Python.

text: To extend Fmt.jl to user-defined types, you'll need to define two methods: `formatinfo` and `formatfield`. So, I think you can define your formatting for measurements, although I've never tried it yet.

elements.text: To extend Fmt.jl to user-defined types, you'll need to define two methods:
formatinfo
and
formatfield
. So, I think you can define your formatting for measurements, although I've never tried it yet.

elements.text: Have you seen

text: Of course! I thought that the interface of Formatting.jl is a little bit awkward, so I've redesigned it from a different aspect (i.e., using a string macro). Also, performance is dramatically improved. Please check the performance section there: <https://github.com/bicycle1885/Fmt.jl#performance>.

elements.text: Of course! I thought that the interface of Formatting.jl is a little bit awkward, so I've redesigned it from a different aspect (i.e., using a string macro). Also, performance is dramatically improved. Please check the performance section there:

text: Ths looks great! More optimized IO/string manipulation in Julia is a welcome sight :) and with easy syntax, too! Make sure to make a package announcement on Discourse at release

elements.text: Ths looks great! More optimized IO/string manipulation in Julia is a welcome sight :) and with easy syntax, too! Make sure to make a package announcement on Discourse at release

text: Thank you! The first release may take a few more weeks because I need to implement error checks and support more types (currently, string, integers, and floats are the only supported types in Fmt.jl). Once it is released, I'll definitely announce it on Discourse.

elements.text: Thank you! The first release may take a few more weeks because I need to implement error checks and support more types (currently, string, integers, and floats are the only supported types in Fmt.jl). Once it is released, I'll definitely announce it on Discourse.

text: Wow, this looks like it'll be super handy. I've been looking for something that has Python-like string formatting since thats I'm used to. Thanks for taking the time to make it!

text: <@U6T475RL1> Had you looked at the string formatting in Strs.jl? That has been available for years now.

elements.text: Had you looked at the string formatting in Strs.jl? That has been available for years now.

text: <@UB7JS9CHF> No, I didn't know that package. Is it (mostly) compatible with Python's string format?

elements.text: No, I didn't know that package. Is it (mostly) compatible with Python's string format?

text:
Yes (although that part could use a bit of work to better match Python‚Äôs latest formatted strings) as well as supporting C printf style formatting, and a lot of other features (such as being able to define defaults for formatted output based on type), outputting LaTeX, Emoji, HTML, and Unicode entities.  I‚Äôve been planning on adding support for ANSI color sequences as well.
```julia> f"This is a LaTeX entity: \<dagger>, HTML: \&eacute; Emoji: \:flag-us:"
"This is a LaTeX entity: ‚Ä†, HTML: √© Emoji: üá∫üá∏"```

elements.text: Yes (although that part could use a bit of work to better match Python‚Äôs latest formatted strings) as well as supporting C printf style formatting, and a lot of other features (such as being able to define defaults for formatted output based on type), outputting LaTeX, Emoji, HTML, and Unicode entities.  I‚Äôve been planning on adding support for ANSI color sequences as well.

julia> f"This is a LaTeX entity: \<dagger>, HTML: \é Emoji: \:flag-us:"
"This is a LaTeX entity: ‚Ä†, HTML: √© Emoji: üá∫üá∏"

text:
Here are some formatted output (C style and using type based defaults):
```julia> f"Formatted output: <\%12.8g(pi)> <\%-10.3f(pi)> \%(pi) \%(pi/2) \%'12d(typemax(Int))"
"Formatted output: <   3.1415927> <3.142     > œÄ 1.570796 9,223,372,036,854,775,807"```

elements.text: Here are some formatted output (C style and using type based defaults):

text:
Currently, the Python style (I started on this *before* Python 3.6 - with PEP 498 - came out at the very end of 2016), doesn‚Äôt match Python‚Äôs f-strings, I‚Äôd like to make the syntax closer.
```julia> str = "abc" ; f"\{>4s}(str) + \{.2f}(12)"
" abc + 12.00"```

before

text:
<@U6T475RL1> Hopefully we could combine efforts on this.
Note: I also designed StrLiterals to be extensible, so that it is easy to add other things, such as interned strings, color, etc.

text: Unfortunately, I couldn't install Strs.jl in a fresh Julia environment on Julia 1.6. The error message says "Error building Emoji_Entities".

elements.text: Unfortunately, I couldn't install Strs.jl in a fresh Julia environment on Julia 1.6. The error message says "Error building Emoji_Entities".

text: I think our goals are different. My goal with Fmt.jl is to create a lightweight string format library compatible with Python's format syntax. I'm not willing to make it depend on any other packages.

elements.text: I think our goals are different. My goal with Fmt.jl is to create a lightweight string format library compatible with Python's format syntax. I'm not willing to make it depend on any other packages.

text: You don‚Äôt have to install all of Strs.jl, that‚Äôs just the easiest way to get everything all bundled together.

elements.text: You don‚Äôt have to install all of Strs.jl, that‚Äôs just the easiest way to get everything all bundled together.

text: And it is depending on JuliaIO/Formatting.jl already.

elements.text: And it is depending on JuliaIO/Formatting.jl already.

text:
All that is needed is the following:
```julia> using StrLiterals, Format, StrFormat

julia> f"\%(123)"
"123"```

elements.text: All that is needed is the following:

julia> using StrLiterals, Format, StrFormat

julia> f"\%(123)"
"123"

text: That‚Äôs just as lightweight - and it would be trivial to have a package that simply bundled those 3 packages.

elements.text: That‚Äôs just as lightweight - and it would be trivial to have a package that simply bundled those 3 packages.

text: Do I need to load all the three packages to use the f-string macro?

elements.text: Do I need to load all the three packages to use the f-string macro?

text: Ah, no, really just `using StrLiterals, StrFormat`

elements.text: Ah, no, really just
using StrLiterals, StrFormat

text: StrLiterals adds the f, F, pr, PR macros (the f and pr have Swift-compatible syntax for things like `\u{1f596}` instead of having `\U0001F596` , and using `\(‚Ä¶)` for plain string interpolation), which allows you to use `$` as a regular character. The uppercase ‚Äúcompatibility‚Äù versions also allow `$` for interpolation and `\uXXXX` and `\U000XXXXX` for Unicode characters.

text: The `pr` (and `PR` string macros) are useful for debugging, and they also are more efficient because they don‚Äôt cause extra allocations building up a string before printing.

elements.text: The
pr
(and
PR
string macros) are useful for debugging, and they also are more efficient because they don‚Äôt cause extra allocations building up a string before printing.

text: You can send it to different I/O simply by: `pr"\(stderr)Send it to error output!\n"`

elements.text: You can send it to different I/O simply by:

text: I see. So, the syntax is different from that of Python, and we are making different packages with different format syntaxes with different APIs.

elements.text: I see. So, the syntax is different from that of Python, and we are making different packages with different format syntaxes with different APIs.

text: Well, in my README.md, I stated that I intended to change it to match the new Python f-style syntax - I just haven‚Äôt had the time, it should be pretty easy.

elements.text: Well, in my README.md, I stated that I intended to change it to match the new Python f-style syntax - I just haven‚Äôt had the time, it should be pretty easy.

text: It would be at least as close to the Python syntax as what you currently have in Fmt.jl, i.e. `f"\{foo():.2f}"` in mine, vs `f"{$(foo()):.2f}"` in yours (and `f"{foo():.2f}"` in Python 3.6 and later)

text: One thing that I‚Äôd wanted to tackle, is that in Formatting.jl (and Format.jl), there are multiple not entirely consistent formatting ‚Äúengines‚Äù, for C style, Python style, and also for Tom‚Äôs type based extensions.

elements.text: One thing that I‚Äôd wanted to tackle, is that in Formatting.jl (and Format.jl), there are multiple not entirely consistent formatting ‚Äúengines‚Äù, for C style, Python style, and also for Tom‚Äôs type based extensions.
